fact: Soccer is the most popular sport in the world, with over 4 billion fans globally.
A standard soccer match is 90 minutes long, divided into two halves of 45 minutes.
Each soccer team has 11 players on the field at a time.
The FIFA World Cup is the most prestigious soccer tournament, held every 4 years.
The first FIFA World Cup was held in Uruguay in 1930.
A goal is scored when the entire ball crosses the goal line between the goalposts.
The offside rule prevents players from gaining an unfair advantage by being too close to the opponent’s goal.
Yellow cards are used to caution players for misconduct.
Red cards are used to eject players from the game for serious offenses.
The ball used in soccer must be spherical and made of suitable material.
Soccer is called 'football' in most countries outside of North America.
A hat-trick occurs when a player scores three goals in a single game.
Penalty kicks are awarded for fouls committed inside the penalty box.
The goalkeeper is the only player allowed to use their hands, and only within the penalty area.
Substitutions allow teams to replace tired or injured players during a match.
Extra time is used when a knockout match ends in a draw.
Penalty shootouts decide the winner when extra time ends in a draw.
Lionel Messi and Cristiano Ronaldo are among the most famous soccer players in history.
Brazil has won the most FIFA World Cups, with five titles.
The UEFA Champions League is the top European club competition.
The Premier League is the top professional soccer league in England.
VAR (Video Assistant Referee) helps referees review key decisions.
Soccer was first included in the Olympics in 1900 for men and 1996 for women.
The standard soccer pitch is about 100 to 110 meters long.
The captain wears an armband and leads the team on the field.
Throw-ins are used to restart play when the ball goes out over the sidelines.
Corners are awarded when the defending team last touches the ball before it crosses their goal line.
Free kicks are awarded after fouls, with direct and indirect types.
Handballs occur when a player deliberately handles the ball with their hand or arm.
The referee is in charge of enforcing the rules during a match.
Assistant referees help judge offsides and out-of-bounds calls.
A clean sheet refers to a game in which the goalkeeper allows no goals.
A brace means a player scored two goals in one game.
A golden goal used to end a match as soon as one team scored in extra time, but it is no longer used.
A bicycle kick is an acrobatic move where a player kicks the ball backward over their own head.
A derby refers to a match between two local rival teams.
FIFA stands for Fédération Internationale de Football Association.
The Ballon d'Or is awarded annually to the best male footballer.
The Women's World Cup was first held in 1991.
